Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High-Performance, Low-Cost Anode-Free Lithium-Ion Batteries for Electric Vehicles and Consumer Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to create a new type of lithium-ion battery for electric vehicle (EV) battery packs. Passenger vehicles representing 27% of global oil consumption. The proposed material will enable a new affordable, long-range EV reducing battery costs by reducing the battery size by 65% and the cell cost by up to 40%. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project proposes to understand the influence of formation conditions and electrolyte composition on the generation of anode-free solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) using electrochemical and thin film characterization techniques. In the absence of a robust SEI, anode-free batteries experience rapid capacity loss that stems from either “mossy” lithium growth or precipitous electrolyte decomposition. These degradation routes result in cells that typically function for less than 50 cycles at room temperature. The impact of formation temperature and current density on anode-free SEI formation during galvanostatic charge/discharge will be analyzed using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) as well as conventional electrochemical techniques. These techniques will also measure the impact of varying electrolyte salt/solvent compositions on anode-free SEI formation. The dependence of temperature on cycle life with the optimized SEI conditions will be evaluated through galvanostatic charge/discharge. The key objective of the project is to clarify the formation conditions and electrolyte composition that results in the generation of a smooth SEI layer featuring ideal lithium mosaic columns capable of reversibly cycling with minimal capacity fade at room temperature.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eonix is developing the first commercially viable Anode-free battery that increases the energy density of lithium ion batteries by nearly 2.5X and increases the specific energy by 35% to reduce the overall pack level cost of lithium ion batteries in electric vehicles by 40%. In this novel design, the anode material is supplanted by a copper current collector that is plated with lithium from the cathode on the first cycle thereby safely constructing a lithium metal anode. This approach maximizes energy density (1500 Wh/L) by ensuring only the active lithium ions, the ions are exchanged between the cathode and anode during cycling, are present in the cell.

Prior to the Phase I work performed under this NSF SBIR award, Eonix?s highest performance electrolyte in anode-free devices could only charge/discharge for 42 cycles before shorting and lost 20% of its initial capacity after the first 18 cycles. The primary focus of this SBIR Phase I work was to clarify the optimal conditions to generate a smooth/uniform SEI on the copper anode, understand the impact of electrolyte composition on anode-free SEI formation, and identify the performance limitations at lower temperatures.

During this Phase I work, Eonix fabricated 114 lithium ion battery test cells (56 cells with Nickel Manganese Cobalt Oxide 532 and 58 cells with Lithium iron phosphate), evaluated 19 different electrolyte compositions, and conducted post-mortem characterization on 38 copper anodes with Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). By leveraging the electrolyte component and SEI formation insights gained during this Phase I project, the performance of the anode free electrolyte was significantly improved at room temperature. The final electrolyte evaluated that was optimally formed in an anode-free device was able to charge/discharge for 146 cycles prior to shorting and lost 20% of its capacity after 59 cycles. This represents a 3X improvement in cycle life in both total and 20% capacity fade lifetime for an anode-free device at room temperature. 

In addition to the significant electrochemical improvements observed in the anode-free electrolyte, Eonix also cultivated a robust understanding of the organo-electrochemical structure activity relationships that dictate solid electrolyte interphase formation on copper substrates. These insights will be further leveraged to continuing improving the cycle life of the anode-free electrolyte for electric vehicle and consumer electronics applications. 

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Donald Derosa

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Eonix is developing the first commercially viable Anode-free battery that increases the energy density of lithium ion batteries by nearly 2.5X and increases the specific energy by 35% to reduce the overall pack level cost of lithium ion batteries in electric vehicles by 40%. In this novel design, the anode material is supplanted by a copper current collector that is plated with lithium from the cathode on the first cycle thereby safely constructing a lithium metal anode. This approach maximizes energy density (1500 Wh/L) by ensuring only the active lithium ions, the ions are exchanged between the cathode and anode during cycling, are present in the cell. Prior to the Phase I work performed under this NSF SBIR award, Eonix?s highest performance electrolyte in anode-free devices could only charge/discharge for 42 cycles before shorting and lost 20% of its initial capacity after the first 18 cycles. The primary focus of this SBIR Phase I work was to clarify the optimal conditions to generate a smooth/uniform SEI on the copper anode, understand the impact of electrolyte composition on anode-free SEI formation, and identify the performance limitations at lower temperatures. In addition to the significant electrochemical improvements observed in the anode-free electrolyte, Eonix also cultivated a robust understanding of the organo-electrochemical structure activity relationships that dictate solid electrolyte interphase formation on copper substrates. These insights will be further leveraged to continuing improving the cycle life of the anode-free electrolyte for electric vehicle and consumer electronics applications.
